thread.title: Highlands keeps streak vs. CovCath alive
thread.title_full: Highlands keeps streak vs. CovCath alive

title: Highlands keeps streak vs. CovCath alive
text:
Highlands keeps streak vs. CovCath alive Rick Broering, Enquirer contributor 7:14 p.m. EDT October 17, 2015 Buy Photo Covington Catholic's Ryan McGinness runs the ball during the Colonels' 14-10 loss to Highland's Saturday. Tony Tribble for The Enquirer Buy Photo Buy Photo Covington Catholic wide receiver Cam Pitzer runs the ball during the Colonels' football game against Highlands Saturday. Tony Tribble for The Enquirer Buy Photo Fullscreen Buy Photo Covington Catholic running back Anthony Best reacts after scoring a touchdown during the Colonels' football game against Highlands Saturday. Tony Tribble for The Enquirer Buy Photo Highlands' Jared Pulsfort runs for a touchdown during the Bluebirds' football game against Covington Catholic Saturday. Tony Tribble for The Enquirer Buy Photo Buy Photo Highlands' Jared Pulsfort reacts after scoring a touchdown during the Bluebirds' football game against Covington Catholic Saturday. Tony Tribble for The Enquirer Buy Photo Buy Photo Highlands quarterback Austin Hergott drops back to pass during the Bluebirds' football game against Covington Catholic Saturday. Tony Tribble for The Enquirer Buy Photo Fullscreen Buy Photo Highlands wide receiver Braden Posey (87) catches a pass during the Bluebirds' football game against Covington Catholic Saturday. Tony Tribble for The Enquirer Covington Catholic quarterback AJ Maye runs the ball during the Colonels' football game against Highlands Saturday. Tony Tribble for The Enquirer Buy Photo Covington Catholic quarterback AJ Maye is wrapped up by Highlands defenders during their football game Saturday. Tony Tribble for The Enquirer Buy Photo Fullscreen Buy Photo Highlands quarterback Austin Hergott (7) is sacked by Covington Catholic's Jack Maile (43) during their football game Saturday. Tony Tribble for The Enquirer Buy Photo Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Last Slide Next Slide Buy Photo Highlands wide receiver Braden Posey (87) catches a pass during the Bluebirds' football game against Covington Catholic Saturday. (Photo: Tony Tribble for The Enquirer) Buy Photo 31 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Saturday’s annual rivalry match-up between Covington Catholic and Highlands was played under unusual circumstances as both teams entered with 2-5 records, atypical of their normal winning ways. 
However, the end result was a familiar one as the Bluebirds beat the Colonels, 14-10, at Wooten Field in Park Hills. 
CovCath outgained Highlands 319-198 in total yards and held a 10-0 lead in the second quarter, but the Bluebirds had a pair of timely touchdown runs and a 3-0 advantage in the turnover column. Juniors Jared Pulsfort and Grant Murray ran for Highlands’ only touchdowns on the day. 
The win marked Highlands’ 13th consecutive victory over CovCath, a streak that dates back to 2006 when CovCath made its last state title run. The Bluebirds now lead the all-time series 46-17. 
“We always love beating CovCath,” Murray said. “It’s always a big rivalry and a good game.” 
Murray’s 13-yard touchdown run up the middle on the opening drive of the second half with 10:02 to play in the third quarter put Highlands ahead for good. CovCath had five more possessions to answer, but was only able to muster 81 yards after halftime. 
“That was the turning point in the game,” Murray said of his touchdown. “That was our mentality the whole game – run it right at them and play smash-mouth football. That’s what we kept doing, and it worked.” 
The Colonels’ best chance to retake the lead came in the fourth quarter when they constructed a nine-play drive that took them inside the Bluebirds’ 30 with under four minutes to play, but Highlands junior Bradley Greene picked off CovCath quarterback AJ Mayer at the 5 and returned the ball back to the 50. 
CovCath had one more shot, starting from its own 28 with 1:46 to play in the game, but junior Trey Bowden picked Mayer off again on the second play of the drive to seal the Bluebirds’ win. 
According to coach Brian Weinrich, both Greene and Bowden had recently been moved from the offensive side of the ball to the defensive side due to injuries. 
“(The defensive performance) was huge,” Weinrich said. “We knew if we could just keep the game in front of us and play smart (we’d be fine). The two big interceptions … those guys were offensive guys a couple of weeks ago. They’ve been getting better in practice, and they made huge plays.” 
Senior Jared Dougherty and junior Sam Taylor led Highlands’ defense, which stepped up huge in the second half. Dougherty was in on a team-high 11 tackles, and Taylor had 10, including nine solo. Senior Luke Lindeman forced the Colonels’ other turnover when he sacked Mayer on the opening drive of the game, jarring the ball loose. Senior Austin Mayhew came up with the recovery. 
Highlands quarterback Austin Hergott was sharp all game, finishing with just two incompletions. He was 9-for-11 for 93 yards. 
“This is awesome,” Hergott said. “Being here and doing this in this atmosphere is insane.” 
Highlands 0 7 7 0 - 14 
CovCath 3 7 0 0 - 10 
C – Kloska 21 field goal 
C – Best 4 run (Kloska kick) 
H – Pulsfort 5 run (Dougherty kick) 
H – Murray 13 run (Dougherty kick) 
Records: H 3-5, C 2-6 31 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://cin.ci/1LANEa9 TOP VIDEOS
